citations.narrative:
There is incomplete information on the acquisition records for one adult female hyacinth macaw and one adult female
blue and gold macaw. These records are incomplete because they do not have the additional identification information
necessary for persons who are not licensed or registered under the Animal Welfare Act. This information is needed to
help track the movements of covered species and help ensure they are used in a humane manner.
The licensee must ensure that all information required under Part 2, Subpart G, Section 2.75(b) is captured in the
acquisition and disposition records for all covered animals, to include the vehicle license number and State, and the
driver's license number (or photographic identification card for nondrivers issued by a State) and State of the person, if he
or she is not licensed or registered under the Animal Welfare Act.
TO BE CORRECTED BY 11/22/2023

There are three head of cattle, seven pigs, one sheep and one rhea housed in outdoor pens without public barrier fencing
or a facility attendant present. At the time of inspection, three members of the public are seen reaching through the pen
fencing to pet and offer food to these animals.
Public barriers or facility attendants are important to protect both the animals and people; people or animals can be
injured by unsupervised, direct contact and animals can become ill if they eat food or objects presented to them by
people. The licensee must ensure that there is sufficient distance and effective barriers of sufficient height and integrity
between the animals and the general viewing public whenever a responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable
employee is not present during periods of public contact.
TO BE CORRECTED BY 11/22/2023

At the time of inspection, three members of the public are seen reaching through fences of animal pens to offer food they
brought to the facility to three head of cattle, seven pigs, one sheep and one rhea. Animals can become ill if they eat food
not provided by the animal facility or objects presented to them by people. The licensee must ensure that, if public feeding
of animals is allowed, all food must be provided by the animal facility and shall be appropriate for the type of animal and
its nutritional needs and diet.
TO BE CORRECTED BY 11/22/2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1)(iii) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
There is incomplete information on the acquisition records for one adult female hyacinth macaw and one adult female 
blue and gold macaw. These records are incomplete because they do not have the additional identification information 
necessary for persons who are not licensed or registered under the Animal Welfare Act. This information is needed to 
help track the movements of covered species and help ensure they are used in a humane manner. 
The licensee must ensure that all information required under Part 2, Subpart G, Section 2.75(b) is captured in the 
acquisition and disposition records for all covered animals, to include the vehicle license number and State, and the 
driver's license number (or photographic identification card for nondrivers issued by a State) and State of the person, if he 
or she is not licensed or registered under the Animal Welfare Act. 
TO BE CORRECTED BY 11/22/2023 
2.131(d)(2) 
   
Handling of animals. 
There are three head of cattle, seven pigs, one sheep and one rhea housed in outdoor pens without public barrier fencing 
or a facility attendant present. At the time of inspection, three members of the public are seen reaching through the pen 
fencing to pet and offer food to these animals.  
Public barriers or facility attendants are important to protect both the animals and people; people or animals can be 
injured by unsupervised, direct contact and animals can become ill if they eat food or objects presented to them by 
people. The licensee must ensure that there is sufficient distance and effective barriers of sufficient height and integrity 
between the animals and the general viewing public whenever a responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable 
employee is not present during periods of public contact.  
TO BE CORRECTED BY 11/22/2023 
2.131(d)(4) 
   
Handling of animals. 
At the time of inspection, three members of the public are seen reaching through fences of animal pens to offer food they 
brought to the facility to three head of cattle, seven pigs, one sheep and one rhea. Animals can become ill if they eat food 
not provided by the animal facility or objects presented to them by people. The licensee must ensure that, if public feeding 
of animals is allowed, all food must be provided by the animal facility and shall be appropriate for the type of animal and

its nutritional needs and diet.  
TO BE CORRECTED BY 11/22/2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
